Arthur McGregor

Software Developer · Christchurch, New Zealand · arthur.mcgregor@gmail.com

I am a committed, motivated and adaptable professional. I am an effective problem-solver with a degree in Civil Engineering. After 9 years as a registered teacher, I can communicate clearly to diverse audiences. With broad volunteer experience I have strong collaboration and leadership skills. This year I am completing a Graduate Diploma in IT to develop my technical skills and adapt my workflow. I am excited about this career change and will be ready to enter the IT industry in November.

Portfolio

hiko.kiwi

Electric Vehicle Charging Map (personal project)

hiko.kiwi

This personal project has been an enjoyable learning experience. As an electric vehicle (EV) driver, I need to know where the nearest fast charge stations are. Although there are many maps already available, this is a unique solution because it shows full details for current stations, as well as under construction and future chargers. In addition, you can view a list of all chargers and identify the nearest chargers to your current position. The app is a fully responsive, progressive web app, with Google Analytics tracking and automatic deployment from GitHub.

hiko.kiwi has been built in VueJS, is hosted on Google's Firebase platform, with a supporting server built in NodeJS and hosted on Heroku. The map service is provided by Mapbox which allows for a high level of customisation. The server runs a script daily to fetch the station data from two sources. The first EVROAM, a REST API which provides a JSON of all active and under construction stations that meet NZTA criteria. The second is a Google Map which displays all active, under construction and future stations. This requires processing from a KML into a GeoJSON and filtering to remove duplication.

2018

Cacophony Project

Open Source

The Cacophony Project is using modern technology to eliminate predators such as possums, rats and stoats, so that we can restore our dawn chorus. The 'cacophonator' will lure predators with sound and light, use a thermal camera and machine learning algorithms to identify the predator, and finally eliminate the predator using a mechanised air gun that fires a sticky poison pellet.

I have been involved since early June 2018 as a volunteer contributor. I am primarily helping to improve the web portal which allows for remote monitoring of the cacophonators. In particular, I have assisted with the transition from Node/Express to VueJS which has involved rebuilding the app from the ground up to be more mobile responsive and easier to maintain in the long term. Most of my time has been spent building the query interface and recording view page. I am enjoying working on a project that aligns with my passions as an environmentalist, as well as learning new skills and working with a diverse team.

View my contributions on GitHub

Education

Graduate Diplome in Information and Communication Technologies

SIGNAL ICT Graduate School (Ara and UC)

Through engaging industry-related projects my team and I have applied agile methodology to create software solutions. I have learnt new technologies appropriate to the needs of each project and held various roles within the group to identify the client requirements and develop a viable product. The Shift programme included visiting a variety of IT companies which has all combined to affirm my decision to change careers.

  • Electives:
    • COSC 122 : Introduction to Computer Science
      This course has covered fundamental data structures and algorithms, including recursion, sorting, searching, trees and graphs, implemented in Python.
    • COSC 265 : Relational Database Systems
      This course has covered database design, the relational data model, SQL, normalisation, and physical level implementation, using Oracle.
  • Industry project at Orbica
    • My internship at Orbica has involved creating a website to support the onboarding process for a product under development. Working with another intern and interacting with the wider product team, I have identified user requirements and developed user personas. This led to a range of prototype designs that were refined into a final product. This was integrated with the existing CMS to ensure the project was manageable in the long term.

Teaching Experience

Christ's College

Teacher of Physics and Technology
  • I was heavily involved in the deployment of a new IT system 'Schoolbox'. This acted as a combined portal, intranet and learning management system. I was able to quickly learn how the system worked and became the lead 'Champion' in its delivery. I was given 'superuser' admin rights which enabled me to assist my colleagues one-on-one and when leading professional development workshops. I attended the Schoolbox Meetup 2017 in Melbourne where I presented on our implementation journey. I was also a member of the ICT committee.
  • I developed an innovative cross-curricular course for Year 11 students which combined aspects of Physics with Technology. With a space exploration theme, students developed prototype Martian rovers using Arduino microprocessors then used their Physics knowledge to design, build and launch model rockets. Developing this course required me to integrate knowledge and skills from different subject domains, in addition to building positive relationships with a wide range of colleagues. The course was well-received and featured in the College Magazine.
  • I led a team of four staff to review the College academic reporting process. I used my group facilitation skills as we discussed how to reduce workload and improve efficiencies for staff. I summarised our discussion and produced a formal report which was presented to the curriculum leaders for consideration.
  • I was invited to be a member of the Curriculum Review 'Drive Team'. We examined current methodology accross the school, reviewed best practice for curriculum delivery and evaluated options for improvement. I was a strong advocate for change to implement a more modern, flexible and student-focused approach to learning. I presented one option to the staff and subsequently led a workshop discussing the same.
  • As the Teacher in Charge of General Science, I worked with a colleague to develop learning and assessment resources for the General Science courses. Although traditionally seen as a lesser science at the school (compared to the separate science subjects) I was able to nearly double the number of students taking the courses over 2 years. I did this by clearly communicating the course purpose and then delivering relevant and engaging course material.
  • Professional Development:
    • TEDxChristchurch 2016
    • SingularityU Summit
    • Computer Science for High Schools Conference
    • Positive Education and Wellbeing Staff Conference

Volunteer Experience

Spirit of Adventure Trust

Various Positions
  • From late 2013 until 2016? I was an advisory Trustee to the Board. I contribute the perspective of young people, schools and Spirit crew to decision making for this youth development charity.
  • I have sailed frequently as a Watch Leader on the Spirit of New Zealand, which involves instructing trainees in sail handling and ship manoeuvres whilst taking responsibility for their development through the experiential learning process.
  • While at university I was heavily involved in the "Spirit Voyagers' Club". This was a land-based, youth-led, voluntary organisation that ran reunion events for past trainees, supplied Leading Hands as crew onboard, and fundraised to support the Trust. I was the Secretary on the National Committee for 3 years and subsequent Committee Mentor for 2 years.
  • Awards:
    • Topsail Award for services to the Spirit Voyagers' Club, 2011
    • AUSTA Medallion for services to the Spirit Voyagers' Club, 2005
2004 - 2016?

Sail Training International

Chairman & NZ Representative, Youth Council
  • I was the New Zealand representative and Chairman for the Sail Training International Youth Council. This involved leading around 20 representatives from around the world to develop an international community for youth involved in sail training.
  • Through those connections I joined the Cape Windjammers Education Trust in June 2011 for their winter sail training programme. I contributed to both programme design and implementation of the three 5-day voyages in the local area, focusing on youth development and marine education.
2010 - 2014

The Challenge Network, UK

Senior Mentor
  • As a Senior Mentor (paid position), I was responsible for 12 young people as they took part in The Challenge , an English youth development programme focusing on improving inter-personal skills and increasing community cohesion. The programme was partly residential and highly youth led. I completed two three-week programmes, working with a team of 13 staff and 60 young people each time.
2012

Interests

I am passionate about the environment and tackling climate change. My wife and I are electric vehicle enthusiasts and e-bike converts. We enjoy taking our two dogs for walks and developing our native garden. I am the regular cook at home and my favourite way to spend a sunny weekend would be good food, good wine, and good company.

We lived in England for 1 year and travelled through Africa, Europe and the US. More recently we did an Intrepid Food Tour around India. I enjoy travel photography and you can read my blog here .
